title: Victim’s mom won’t watch Benghazi hearing
text:
Victim’s mom won’t watch Benghazi hearing Owen Boss Thursday, October 22, 2015 Photo by: AP Democratic presidential candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton looks toward the dais as she settles into her seat on Capitol Hill in Washington, Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015, prior to testifying before the House Benghazi Committee. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci) Photo by: Nancy Lane TESTIMONY: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, above, is scheduled to testify today about the 2012 Benghazi attack, before a House committee. prev next comments 147 shares Tweet The mother of a CIA contractor and former Navy SEAL killed in the 2012 attack on the U.S. compound in Benghazi says she won’t be watching Hillary Clinton testify before a House committee today because she’s fed up with “politicians pushing this to the nth degree.”
“I will not be watching it, I will not be making comments on it, I have been asked to go to New York and do this and that — I just have to divorce myself from the whole thing,” said Barbara Doherty of Woburn, whose son Glen Doherty died in the attack in Libya.
“This has been going on for so long ... This is just politicians pushing this to the nth degree and hopefully after this hearing it will all be over and it will get better for us,” Doherty told the Herald. “Hopefully some of the politicians in Washington will reshape themselves.”
The Democratic presidential hopeful, who will testify about the attack before the Select Committee on Benghazi, is expected to be peppered with tough questions. And while the former U.S. secretary of state’s testimony won’t close the book on the committee’s more than three-year investigation, Doherty said she hopes it will allow her family to “get this all behind them” so they can “focus on the fight” with the U.S. government and an insurance company for his death benefits.
“It’s not just for us, it’s for the hundreds of other families that also have not received their death benefits. We’re fighting for them, too,” Doherty said. “This has been a three-year journey. I’m not giving up the fight. I might take it to my grave but I’m going to keep on going.”
Doherty last year sued Rutherfoord Insurance, alleging the Virginia company took her son’s money knowing they would not have to pay out death benefits because he wasn’t married and didn’t have children. She also filed a $1 million wrongful death claim with the State Department alleging the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi was improperly secured when her son and three other Americans, including the U.S. ambassador, were killed in a militant attack.
Today’s hearing is set to begin at 10 a.m. and last most of the day. Critics have accused the Republican-controlled panel of dragging out their investigation in an effort to damage Clinton’s presidential aspirations.
